wikipedia_page.main: Percy Hugh Beverley Lyon MC (1893–1986) was a 20th-century British poet and educator, a winner of the Newdigate Prize and headmaster of Rugby School from 1931 to 1948.

Whilst at Rugby Magee fell in love with Elinor Lyon, the daughter of P. H. B. Lyon, the headmaster. She became the inspiration for many of Magee's poems.Sunward I've Climbed. Hermann Hagedorn, The Macmillan Company, New York, 1942. (In this biography, Elinor was referred to as "Diana.") Though his love was not returned, he remained friends with Elinor and her family.

*Kamienie na szaniec (1943);Based on true events, described in Lilka Trzcinska-Croydon, The Labyrinth of Dangerous Hours: A Memoir of the Second World War (Toronto University Press, 2004), with a foreword by Norman Davies. published in English as Stones for the Rampart (London, 1945), with a foreword by P. H. B. Lyon

Elinor Lyon's father was the poet and headmaster P. H. B. Lyon. After a period in Switzerland, she returned to Oxford to read English at Lady Margaret Hall, just as the Second World War began. She completed four terms, then joined the WRNS: "With many... friends being killed, I couldn't stay there reading Milton."Introduction by Elinor Lyon, The House in Hiding, Fidra Books, Edinburgh 2006, ii She served for two-and-half years as a radar operator.

He wrote around 170 songs, and also some pieces for piano and organ.Dictionary of Organs and Organists. 1912 His many ballads became well known throughout the British Isles. He worked with a number of lyricists including Frederic Weatherly KC, Helen Taylor, Edward Teschemacher, P.J. O'Reilly, Lancelot Cayley Shadwell and P. H. B. Lyon.  His songs were often performed at the popular Saturday afternoon concerts at the Royal Albert Hall, presented by Arthur Boosey & Co. They were also performedProm 51, Oct 1914 at the Promenade Concerts, organised by Sir Henry Wood. Sheet music sales of his most successful song, "Until" (1910) sold more than a million copies. It is said that his song "Drake Goes West" (1910) was the first song ever to be broadcast on wireless radio by the BBC.
